member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.NetworkInterface.Bind
member.summary: Method called on unbound adapter (maybe when handling changing *both* the IP/subnet/gateway *and* the wireless settings). This method notifies NDIS to bind the adapter to all protocols indicated in the registry, in effect causing the current registry settings to be applied rather than those which the adapter is currently using. Since we are binding, not *re*-binding the protocols, we are implying that the adapter is not currently bound to anything. When making this call, we must refresh any adapter list that we might have, to retrieve the current state of all adapters. Changes to things like the IP address, subnet mask, etc. are not immediately returned.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.NetworkInterface.Unbind
member.summary: Method called to unbind a given adapter. You might perform this operation before attempting to change *both* the protocol configuration of an adapter (IP, subnet, gateway), *and* the wireless configuration of the same adapter (WEP, SSID, etc.) To do that, first unbind the adapter, then change the settings, then bind the adapter (UnbindAdapter(), make changes, BindAdapter()). Once you have bound/unbound an adapter, to get its new configuration, you must regenerate the list of adapters. Changes to things like the IP address, subnet mask, etc. are not immediately returned.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.NetworkInterface.Rebind
member.summary: Method called after making some changes to the current IP address, subnet mask, etc. This method notifies NDIS to rebind the adapter to all protocols, in effect causing the current registry settings to be applied rather than those which the current configuration represents. Once you have rebound an adapter, to get its new configuration, you must regenerate the list of adapters. Changes to things like the IP address, subnet mask, etc. are not immediately returned.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.DuplicateAddressDetectionState.Invalid
member.summary: The address is not valid. A nonvalid address is expired and no longer assigned to an interface; applications should not send data packets to it.

member.name: T:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus
member.summary: Reports the status of sending an Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) echo message to a computer.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus.Unknown
member.summary: The ICMP echo request failed for an unknown reason.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus.Success
member.summary: The ICMP echo request succeeded; an ICMP echo reply was received. When you get this status code, the other System.Net.NetworkInformation.PingReply properties contain valid data.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus.DestinationNetworkUnreachable
member.summary: The ICMP echo request failed because the network that contains the destination computer is not reachable.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus.DestinationHostUnreachable
member.summary: The ICMP echo request failed because the destination computer is not reachable.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus.DestinationProhibited
member.summary: The ICMP echo request failed because contact with the destination computer is administratively prohibited.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus.DestinationProtocolUnreachable
member.summary: The ICMP echo request failed because the destination computer that is specified in an ICMP echo message is not reachable, because it does not support the packet's protocol.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus.DestinationPortUnreachable
member.summary: The ICMP echo request failed because the port on the destination computer is not available.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus.NoResources
member.summary: The ICMP echo request failed because of insufficient network resources.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus.BadOption
member.summary: The ICMP echo request failed because it contains an invalid option.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus.HardwareError
member.summary: The ICMP echo request failed because of a hardware error.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus.PacketTooBig
member.summary: The ICMP echo request failed because the packet containing the request is larger than the maximum transmission unit (MTU) of a node (router or gateway) located between the source and destination. The MTU defines the maximum size of a transmittable packet.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus.TimedOut
member.summary: The ICMP echo Reply was not received within the allotted time. The default time allowed for replies is 5 seconds. You can change this value using the Overload:System.Net.NetworkInformation.Ping.Send or Overload:System.Net.NetworkInformation.Ping.SendAsync methods that take a timeout parameter.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus.BadRoute
member.summary: The ICMP echo request failed because there is no valid route between the source and destination computers.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus.TtlExpired
member.summary: The ICMP echo request failed because its Time to Live (TTL) value reached zero, causing the forwarding node (router or gateway) to discard the packet.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus.TtlReassemblyTimeExceeded
member.summary: The ICMP echo request failed because the packet was divided into fragments for transmission and all of the fragments were not received within the time allotted for reassembly. RFC 2460 (available at www.ietf.org) specifies 60 seconds as the time limit within which all packet fragments must be received.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus.ParameterProblem
member.summary: The ICMP echo request failed because a node (router or gateway) encountered problems while processing the packet header. This is the status if, for example, the header contains invalid field data or an unrecognized option.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus.SourceQuench
member.summary: The ICMP echo request failed because the packet was discarded. This occurs when the source computer's output queue has insufficient storage space, or when packets arrive at the destination too quickly to be processed.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus.BadDestination
member.summary: The ICMP echo request failed because the destination IP address cannot receive ICMP echo requests or should never appear in the destination address field of any IP datagram. For example, calling Overload:System.Net.NetworkInformation.Ping.Send and specifying IP address "000.0.0.0" returns this status.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus.DestinationUnreachable
member.summary: The ICMP echo request failed because the destination computer that is specified in an ICMP echo message is not reachable; the exact cause of problem is unknown.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus.TimeExceeded
member.summary: The ICMP echo request failed because its Time to Live (TTL) value reached zero, causing the forwarding node (router or gateway) to discard the packet.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus.BadHeader
member.summary: The ICMP echo request failed because the header is invalid.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus.UnrecognizedNextHeader
member.summary: The ICMP echo request failed because the Next Header field does not contain a recognized value. The Next Header field indicates the extension header type (if present) or the protocol above the IP layer, for example, TCP or UDP.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus.IcmpError
member.summary: The ICMP echo request failed because of an ICMP protocol error.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.IPStatus.DestinationScopeMismatch
member.summary: The ICMP echo request failed because the source address and destination address that are specified in an ICMP echo message are not in the same scope. This is typically caused by a router forwarding a packet using an interface that is outside the scope of the source address. Address scopes (link-local, site-local, and global scope) determine where on the network an address is valid.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.ArpTable.CreateProxyArpEntry(OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.NetworkInterface,System.Net.IPAddress,System.Net.IPAddress)
member.summary: This function creates a Proxy Address Resolution Protocol (PARP) entry on the local computer for the specified IP address.
member.param: The NetworkInterface on which to proxy ARP for the IP address specified by the address parameter. In other words, when an ARP request for address is received on this interface, the local computer responds with the physical address of this interface. If this interface is of a type that does not support ARP, such as PPP, then the call fails.
Specifies the IP address for which this computer acts as a proxy. The address must meet the following condition: (address & mask) == address.

Specifies the mask for the IP address specified by the dwAddress parameter. This can be either a host mask, for example, 255.255.255.255, or a subnet mask. If a host mask is used, a proxy is created only for the specified address. If a subnet mask is used, a proxy is created for all IP addresses within the subnet, except for the subnet broadcast address. In the subnet broadcast address, unmasked bits are either all set to zero (0) or all set to 1.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.ArpTable.DeleteProxyArpEntry(OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.NetworkInterface,System.Net.IPAddress,System.Net.IPAddress)
member.summary: This function deletes the PARP entry on the local computer specified by the address and adapter parameters.
member.param: The NetworkInterface on which this computer is supporting proxy ARP for the IP address specified by the address parameter
The IP address for which this computer is acting as a proxy.
The subnet mask for the IP address specified by the address parameter.

member.name: T:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.IPOptions
member.summary: The ip_option_information structure describes the options to be included in the header of an IP packet. The TTL, TOS, and Flags values are carried in specific fields in the header. The OptionsData bytes are carried in the options area following the standard IP header. With the exception of source route options, this data must be in the format to be transmitted on the wire as specified in RFC 791. A source route option should contain the full route - first hop thru final destination - in the route data. The first hop will be pulled out of the data and the option will be reformatted accordingly. Otherwise, the route option should be formatted as specified in RFC 791.

member.summary: The ProcessKey routine makes necessary modifications to the key material of a WPA key before it is passed to WZC routines. The processing done to it depends on how it was generated.
member.param: The key type, indicating how the key material in the structure was originally generated
The configuration being changed
For WPA-PSK passphrase type, the passphrase.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.WirelessZeroConfigNetworkInterface.CheckKeySize(System.String,OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.AuthenticationMode,System.Byte[]@)
member.summary: The CheckKeySize routine checks the incoming WEP or WPA key from the user and throws an exception of an appropriate type, if the key size is wrong or if it contains invalid characters. In this case, it also maps the string key into a byte array of the binary values corresponding to the string, which should represent the hex values in the key.
member.param: The string key to be used. Must consist of a string of hexadecimal digits, for WEP keys and WPA binary keys. May be a passphrase for WPA-PSK, though, which can be 8-63 characters long.
Can be any of the authentication mode types, including WEP and WPA-PSK.
Reference parameter into which the returned binary key value is written. Will be set to null if the input string key is empty.
member.returns: KeyType value indicating the type of the key. Note: for WPAPassphrase type, the caller will still have to encode the password before using it (Key is not set). Note: for WPABinary type, the caller will still have to encrypt the key, although it is converted from hex string to binary by this routine.

member.name: M:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.WirelessZeroConfigNetworkInterface.CheckKeySize(System.Byte[],OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.AuthenticationMode)

member.summary: Sets wireless settings associated with a given interface and AP, adding to, rather than replacing the preferred list of APs. This version of the method is designed for the case where *all* of the options are going to be set, where no initial configuration exists at all and where existing items in the preferred list should be maintained. After this method executes, if it is successful, the specified SSID will be at the top, highest- priority, end of the preferred list.

Is infrastructure
WEP key or WPA shared key string representing hex string (each two characters are converted to a single byte)
Index of the WEP key. Valid values are 1-4
Authentication mode for the connection
Privacy (encryption) mode for the connection
Parameters describing how the connection should use EAP to authenticate the user to the network
member.returns: true if succeeded

member.name: T:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.TcpState
member.summary: Specifies the states of a Transmission Control Protocol (TCP) connection.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.TcpState.Unknown
member.summary: The TCP connection state is unknown.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.TcpState.Closed
member.summary: The TCP connection is closed.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.TcpState.Listen
member.summary: The local endpoint of the TCP connection is listening for a connection request from any remote endpoint.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.TcpState.SynSent
member.summary: The local endpoint of the TCP connection has sent the remote endpoint a segment header with the synchronize (SYN) control bit set and is waiting for a matching connection request.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.TcpState.SynReceived
member.summary: The local endpoint of the TCP connection has sent and received a connection request and is waiting for an acknowledgment.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.TcpState.Established
member.summary: The TCP handshake is complete. The connection has been established and data can be sent.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.TcpState.FinWait1
member.summary: The local endpoint of the TCP connection is waiting for a connection termination request from the remote endpoint or for an acknowledgement of the connection termination request sent previously.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.TcpState.FinWait2
member.summary: The local endpoint of the TCP connection is waiting for a connection termination request from the remote endpoint.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.TcpState.CloseWait
member.summary: The local endpoint of the TCP connection is waiting for a connection termination request from the local user.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.TcpState.Closing
member.summary: The local endpoint of the TCP connection is waiting for an acknowledgement of the connection termination request sent previously.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.TcpState.LastAck
member.summary: The local endpoint of the TCP connection is waiting for the final acknowledgement of the connection termination request sent previously.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.TcpState.TimeWait
member.summary: The local endpoint of the TCP connection is waiting for enough time to pass to ensure that the remote endpoint received the acknowledgement of its connection termination request.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.TcpState.DeleteTcb
member.summary: The transmission control buffer (TCB) for the TCP connection is being deleted.

member.name: T:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.RadioConfiguration
member.summary: Describes configuration parameters for an 802.11 radio

member.name: P:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.RadioConfiguration.BeaconPeriod
member.summary: Specifies the interval between beacon message transmissions. This value is specified in Ksec (1024 sec).

member.name: P:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.RadioConfiguration.ATIMWindow
member.summary: Specifies the announcement traffic information message (ATIM) window in Ksec (1024 sec). The ATIM window is a short time period immediately after the transmission of each beacon in an IBSS configuration. During the ATIM window, any station can indicate the need to transfer data to another station during the following data-transmission window.

member.name: P:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.RadioConfiguration.Frequency
member.summary: Specifies the frequency of the selected channel in kHz.

member.name: P:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.RadioConfiguration.FrequencyHopPattern
member.summary: Specifies the hop pattern used to determine the hop sequence. As defined by the 802.11 standard, the layer management entity (LME) of the physical layer uses a hop pattern to determine the hop sequence.

member.name: P:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.RadioConfiguration.FrequencyHopSet
member.summary: Specifies a set of patterns. The LME of the physical layer uses these patterns to determine the hop sequence

member.name: P:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.RadioConfiguration.FrequencyHopDwellTime
member.summary: Specifies the maximum period of time during which the transmitter should remain fixed on a channel. This interval is described in Ksec (1024 sec).

member.name: T:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.NetworkType
member.summary: Enumeration returned in the NetworkTypeInUse property. Indicates the general type of radio network in use.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.NetworkType.FH
member.summary: Indicates the physical layer of the frequency hopping spread-spectrum radio

member.name: T:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.AuthenticationMode
member.summary: Define authentication types for an adapter.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.AuthenticationMode.Open
member.summary: Specifies IEEE 802.11 Open System authentication mode. In this mode, there are no checks performed during the 802.11 authentication

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.AuthenticationMode.Shared
member.summary: Specifies IEEE 802.11 Shared Key authentication mode. This mode requires the use of a pre-shared Wired Equivalent Privacy (WEP) key for the 802.11 authentication

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.AuthenticationMode.AutoSwitch
member.summary: Specifies auto-switch mode. When using auto-switch mode, the device tries IEEE 802.11 Shared Key authentication mode first. If Shared Key authentication fails, the device attempts to use IEEE 802.11 Open System authentication mode. Note The use of this setting is not recommended

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.AuthenticationMode.WPA
member.summary: Specifies WPA version 1 security for infrastructure mode. Authentication is performed between the supplicant, authenticator, and authentication server over IEEE 802.1X. Encryption keys are dynamic and are derived through the authentication process While in this authentication mode, the device will only associate with an access point whose beacon or probe responses contain the authentication suite of type 1 (802.1X) within the WPA information element (IE). This authentication mode is only valid for infrastructure network modes. The driver must return NDIS_STATUS_NOT_ACCEPTED if its network mode is set to ad hoc.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.AuthenticationMode.WPAPSK
member.summary: Specifies WPA version 1 security for infrastructure mode. Authentication is made between the supplicant and authenticator over IEEE 802.1X. Encryption keys are dynamic and are derived through a pre-shared key used on both the supplicant and authenticator. While in this authentication mode, the device will only associate with an access point whose beacon or probe responses contain the authentication suite of type 2 (pre-shared key) within the WPA information element (IE). This authentication mode is only valid for infrastructure network modes. The driver must return NDIS_STATUS_NOT_ACCEPTED if its network mode is set to ad hoc.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.AuthenticationMode.WPAAdHoc
member.summary: Specifies WPA version 1 security for ad hoc mode. This setting specifies the use of a pre-shared key without IEEE 802.1X authentication. Encryption keys are static and are derived through the pre-shared key. This authentication mode is only valid for ad hoc network modes. The driver must return NDIS_STATUS_NOT_ACCEPTED if its network mode is set to infrastructure.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.AuthenticationMode.Unknown
member.summary: The authentication mode cannot be determined.

member.name: T:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.WLANConfigurationList
member.summary: This class represents the data returned by the WZCQueryInterface() call to WZC. There are several values in the INTF_ENTRY struct returned by that query, including a couple of SSID lists (those SSID values currently 'audible' to the adapter and the preferred list). This type is how those lists are returned.

member.name: T:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.NetworkInterfaceType
member.summary: Specifies types of network interfaces.

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.NetworkInterfaceType.AsymmetricDsl
member.summary: The network interface uses an Asymmetric Digital Subscriber Line (ADSL).

member.summary: The network interface uses asynchronous transfer mode (ATM) for data transmission

member.summary: The network interface uses a basic rate interface Integrated Services Digital Network (ISDN) connection. ISDN is a set of standards for data transmission over telephone lines

member.summary: The network interface uses an Ethernet connection. Ethernet is defined in IEEE standard 802.3

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.NetworkInterfaceType.Ethernet3MegaBit
member.summary: #Mb Ethernet

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.NetworkInterfaceType.FastEthernetFx
member.summary: The network interface uses a Fast Ethernet connection over optical fiber. This type of connection is also known as 100BaseFX

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.NetworkInterfaceType.FastEthernetT
member.summary: The network interface uses a Fast Ethernet connection. Fast Ethernet provides a data rate of 100 megabits per second, known as 100BaseT

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.NetworkInterfaceType.Fddi
member.summary: The network interface uses a Fiber Distributed Data Interface (FDDI) connection. FDDI is a set of standards for data transmission on fiber optic lines in a local area network

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.NetworkInterfaceType.GenericModem
member.summary: The network interface uses a modem

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.NetworkInterfaceType.HighPerformanceSerialBus
member.summary: The network interface uses a High Performance Serial Bus

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.NetworkInterfaceType.IPOverAtm
member.summary: The network interface uses Internet Protocol (IP) in combination with asynchronous transfer mode (ATM) for data transmission

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.NetworkInterfaceType.Isdn
member.summary: The network interface uses a connection configured for ISDN and the X.25 protocol. X.25 allows computers on public networks to communicate using an intermediary computer

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.NetworkInterfaceType.Loopback
member.summary: The network interface is a loopback adapter. Such interfaces are used primarily for testing; no traffic is sent

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.NetworkInterfaceType.MultiRateSymmetricDsl
member.summary: The network interface uses a Multirate Digital Subscriber Line

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.NetworkInterfaceType.Ppp
member.summary: The network interface uses a Point-To-Point protocol (PPP) connection. PPP is a protocol for data transmission using a serial device

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.NetworkInterfaceType.PrimaryIsdn
member.summary: The network interface uses a primary rate interface Integrated Services Digital Network (ISDN) connection. ISDN is a set of standards for data transmission over telephone lines

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.NetworkInterfaceType.RateAdaptDsl
member.summary: The network interface uses a Rate Adaptive Digital Subscriber Line (ADSL).

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.NetworkInterfaceType.Slip
member.summary: The network interface uses a Serial Line Internet Protocol (SLIP) connection. SLIP is defined in IETF RFC 1055

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.NetworkInterfaceType.SymmetricDsl
member.summary: The network interface uses a Symmetric Digital Subscriber Line (SDSL).

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.NetworkInterfaceType.TokenRing
member.summary: The network interface uses a Token-Ring connection. Token-Ring is defined in IEEE standard 802.5

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.NetworkInterfaceType.Tunnel
member.summary: The network interface uses a tunnel connection

member.summary: The interface type is not known

member.name: F:OpenNETCF.Net.NetworkInformation.NetworkInterfaceType.VeryHighSpeedDsl
